title: Best Practices for CloudSlang Content Authoring
content:
General guidelines

This section contains recommendations regarding casing, the naming of the content packs/projects, folders, flows/operations/steps, inputs/outputs, configuration items, acronyms, when to use plural/singular, and legal naming.

Naming

Casing

The names of different types of objects must be consistent. Make sure to use:

  • content pack names or project names. To enhance clarity, use the following pattern: cs-domain|usecase|cp-<version>.jar. For example cs-microsoft-office-365-cp-1.1.1.jar, cs-microfocus-ucmdb-cp-2.0.0.jar

  • lowercase for folder names. For example math, strings, utils

  • snake_case for names of flows, operations, steps, configuration items, input, outputs, and flow variables. For example find_text_in_pdf, return_code
  • UPPERCASE_SNAKE_CASE for results. For example NO_ISSUE_FOUND

Folders

Naming must be consistent across folders. Folder names mustn't exceed 128 characters.

Keep in mind that folder names aren't case-sensitive. This means that you can't name a folder TEST if one called test already exists.

Use the OO common folder names as much as possible. In this way, the folders are aligned to a common naming and as a result, the operations/flows groups will be more visible.

The OO common folder names are:

  • community for content developed by and for the Community
  • integrations for content specific to integration products
  • samples for flows that show how operations and flows can perform simple use cases
  • utils for reusable flows and operations

The following directory structure reflects the nomenclature for a Content Pack that includes utility flows.

Flows, operations, and steps

Naming must be consistent across content entities. Flow names mustn't exceed 128 characters, and aren't case-sensitive.

Use <verb>_<noun> name format for flow and operation names. Also, use create, read, update, delete, or another group as common verbs with get, and set for <verb>. When adding operations or flows to an existing integration, use the existing naming for <verb>. This will ensure consistency with the out-of-the-box flows and operation names. Examples: create_snapshot, get_image_details

It's recommended to rename the steps to match the actual action. When using such content in specific flows, consider renaming the step with the name of the action performed to enhance the clarity of the flow.

Example: the following picture shows that a step named is_status_code_200 is more intuitive than string_equals.

Inputs and outputs

Input and output names must be aligned with common names. For inputs, it's recommended to use common prefixes/suffixes such as:

  • host
  • username
  • password
  • port
  • timeout
  • protocol

You may want to add a prefix with the integration product name or acronym such as:

<product>_host, <product>_username, <product>_password

Examples: ucmdb_host, ucmdb_username, ucmdb_password

The common outputs are return_result, return_code, exception, and error_message.

The return_result is the primary result of an operation.

The return_code is an internal code: 0 for success, and -1 for failure. A return_code is used to find the response of a step.

The exception is the exception stack trace, which is mainly used for debugging the root cause in case of failures.

The error_message is the message used to propagate exception messages between steps and flows. 

Configuration items

The following format is recommended for configuration item names:

<configuration item prefix>_<project name>_<type>

The Configuration item prefix consists of the category initials. For example, sl for selection lists, sa for system accounts.

The Project name is simply the project to which the configuration item belongs.

The Type is the configuration item type, such as selection lists, system accounts, and system properties.

Using the recommended format enables you to better differentiate the following:

  • A flow variable from a configuration item.
  • Configuration items by their categories. The prefix helps to distinguish between a selection list and a system account
  • Configuration items by the project name. Example: a selection list that belongs to the REST Project or another project
  • Configuration items by their type. Example: the system property that contains the URL from that containing the proxy host

You can structure configuration items in folders to avoid working with too long names.

    

Acronyms

Use lowercase for abbreviations used in names of the folder, flow, operation names, inputs, and outputs. For example url, sql, http, html

Plural versus singular

Use plurals for folder names.
Examples: servers, databases, operating_systems, images

Use singular for flows and operations that interact with a single resource, such as getting details on a device.
Examples: get_server_details, run_script_on_server

Legal naming

Following are the valid characters for naming folders, operations, flows, and configuration items:

  • Alphanumeric characters
  • Underscores, hyphens

The following strings are reserved names and you shouldn't include them in flow names, configuration item names, and folder names:

  • CON, PRN, AUX, CLOCK, NUL, COM1, COM9, LPT1, COM9

Folder structure

This section describes how to organize content within folders to create a consistent folder structure.

Content structuring

Make sure that the folder structure is well defined and consistent across projects so that other authors can locate your flows, operations, and utilities. Organize the content according to functionality/use case/product:

/Library/<company_publisher>/<domain>/area/<use_case_project>/version

  • company_publisher–Having a common top-level folder separates your developed content from that of OO, and also makes it easier to set permissions.
  • domain–The domain is typically tied to larger groups within the organization and the logical separation by technologies. Examples: remediation, incident_management, cloud, virtualization
  • area (optional)–Depending on the number of flows and size of your organization, this can create an extra layer based upon either a technical or functional area. Example: linux 
  • use_case/project–This level offers a variety of uses, much of which depends on the type and pace of development of OO flows. Example: restart_server
  • version (optional)–Useful when you must run several versions of the same flow at the same time. Examples: Library/myCompany/remediation/v1_0/linux/restart_server 
Note: For multiple versions of the same flow, use the versioning capabilities of Workflow Designer. For more details, see Set up and work with SCM in Workflow Designer. 

Handling multiple integration product versions

The folder structure of the integrations must be kept small. When you create integrations with many products for the same vendor, consider organizing the flows and operations in a folder structure containing the official vendor and official product names (or acronyms such as ALM, QC):

../integrations/vendor/product/product_version

Example:

…/integrations/micro_focus/ucmdb/2_0_0

Create operations or flows

For basic operations, such as CRUD, it's recommended that you create operations rather than flows. Also, developing operations is a good choice when you need to support multiple product versions or hide complex API in atomic operations. Also, programming features such as refactoring provided by different IDEs (such as Atom and IntelliJ) help you speed up the development and maintenance time. 

For example, in wait flows with many steps you don't want to create busy wait loops in flows because this makes triage results difficult. Writing a new wait operation allows for smaller granularity checking, without creating hundreds of tracked results in the OO run logs.

     

On the other hand, creating new operations involves development and test time, while flows can use out-of-the-box operations that have been already tested. To avoid these additional resource requirements, it's a best practice to create common and modular code you can reuse.

Descriptions

Operations and flows  

The operations/flows must have clear and consistent descriptions. These descriptions should include the following sections:

Description is a summary of the operation/flow functionality. It should contain enough information to understand the use case.

  • For inputs, the following items are required for each input whenever the information is applicable and available:
    • Description
    • Format
    • Default Values
    • Valid Values
    • Examples
  • For results, the following items are required for each:
    • Description
    • Format
    • Examples

Notes (optional) is a custom note section that contains prerequisites, some limitations, or other information deemed useful for the user.

Keywords (optional) are a section to help the flow/operation to be found in searches.

It's recommended that all inputs and outputs are documented in the description and that they're listed in the same order in which they appear in the Inputs tab. The following items should be put in double quotation marks when used in a sentence:

  • Inputs
  • Responses or results
  • Examples and values

Example: You must specify a value for the “proxy_host” input. Following is an example of a long description spread across multiple lines:

The Results section contains the description of each response.

The accepted and recommended HTML tags inside the descriptions are:

a, b, blockquote, br, cite, code, dd, dl, dt, em, i, li, ol, p, pre, q, small, span, strike, strong, sub, sup, u, ul, and appropriate attributes.

Additional description recommendations

In Descriptions, use:

  • expressions with second person singular instead of third person neutral. For example, instead of "if a value for this input is not specified, the operation uses the default value", use  "if you do not specify a value for this input, the operation will use the default value".
  • the same syntax for section headings everywhere in the description. For example use “examples” instead of “e.g.” or “ex”.
  • enclose between apostrophes the values from "format ", "examples", "default values", and "valid values". Example: Default Value: ‘,’
  • Add a line with keywords at the end of the description. This is particularly helpful for shared and reusable content. For example incident management

Date and time, numbers and units

The representation of Date and Time, Numbers, and Units must be consistent.

When integrating with a certain product consider using the date and time specific to the integration product. If you report the details of the events from a system, then the expectation is to have the date in the same format. If there is a need for conversion, use the Date and Time content.

You should use the most common and specific units. Asking the user to give a timeout in milliseconds or a disk size in kilobytes simply creates extra calculations.

Examples: Prefer seconds over milliseconds, base 10 (MegaBytes) over base 2 (Mebibyte).
